title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Predictor <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7) Criterion <- c(7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11) BivariateData <- construct(Predictor, Criterion)

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code obtains descriptive statistics data frame.
code: (BivariateData) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                 N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt Predictor  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 Criterion  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 (BivariateData) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`           Predictor Criterion Predictor     1.000     0.533 Criterion     0.533     1.000

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: section produces analyses overall regression model. code produce source table associated regression model.
code: (BivariateData) |> describeModel() $`Source Table for the Regression Model`            SS      df      MS Model  12.500   1.000  12.500 Error  31.500   8.000   3.938 Total  44.000   9.000   4.889

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code produce confidence interval R Squared. code defaults 90% confidence intervals. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateModel() $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model`           Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.555 (BivariateData) |> estimateModel(conf.level = .95) $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model`           Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.600

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code calculate NHST regression model.
code: (BivariateData) |> testModel() $`Hypothesis Test for the Regression Model`             F     df1     df2       p Model   3.175   1.000   8.000   0.113

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: section analyses regression coefficients obtained overall model.

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code provide table confidence intervals regression coefficients. code produce graph confidence intervals regression coefficients.  code defaults 95% confidence intervals. can changed desired. graph, possible plot just coefficients predictors (minus intercept) addition changing confidence level. comparison line region practical equivalence can also added.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateCoefficients() $`Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -4.415  13.082 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateData) |> plotCoefficients() (BivariateData) |> estimateCoefficients(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -8.397  17.063 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403 (BivariateData) |> plotCoefficients(conf.level = .99, line = 0, rope = c(-.5, .5), intercept = FALSE)

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code produce table NHST separately regression coefficients. case, coefficients tested value zero.
code: (BivariateData) |> testCoefficients() $`Hypothesis Tests for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE       t       p (Intercept)   4.333   3.794   1.142   0.286 Predictor     0.833   0.468   1.782   0.113

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code provide table confidence intervals standardized coefficient. places, code defaults 95% confidence interval. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateData) |> standardizeCoefficients() $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients`               Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateData) |> standardizeCoefficients(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients`               Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: section provides analyses individual predicted values.

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code produces plot regression line (confidence prediction intervals suppressed).  code adds scatter data points regression plot.
code: (BivariateData) |> plotRegression(interval = "none") (BivariateData) |> plotRegression(interval = "none", points = TRUE)

title: Bivariate Regression Data Example
text: code provides estimates confidence prediction limits specific value Predictor (value=4). code plots confidence interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.  code plots prediction interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.
code: (BivariateData) |> estimateRegression(value = 8) $`Confidence and Prediction Intervals for the Regression Value`       Est   CI.LL   CI.UL   PI.LL   PI.UL 8  11.000   9.553  12.447   6.201  15.799 (BivariateData) |> plotRegression(value = 8, interval = "confidence") (BivariateData) |> plotRegression(value = 8, interval = "prediction")

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code inputs variable summaries creates summary table. code creates correlation matrix.
code: Predictor <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 1.414) Criterion <- c(N = 10, M = 11.000, SD = 2.211) BivariateSummary <- construct(Predictor, Criterion, class = "wss") Predictor <- c(1.000, .533) Criterion <- c(.533, 1.000) BivariateCorr <- construct(Predictor, Criterion, class = "corr")

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code confirms descriptive statistics summary tables.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                 N       M      SD Predictor  10.000   8.000   1.414 Criterion  10.000  11.000   2.211 (BivariateCorr) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`           Predictor Criterion Predictor     1.000     0.533 Criterion     0.533     1.000

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: section produces analyses overall regression model. code produce source table associated regression model.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> describeModel(BivariateCorr) $`Source Table for the Regression Model`            SS      df      MS Model  12.499   1.000  12.499 Error  31.498   8.000   3.937 Total  43.997   9.000   4.889

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code produce confidence interval R Squared. code defaults 90% confidence intervals. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> estimateModel(BivariateCorr) $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model`           Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.555 (BivariateSummary) |> estimateModel(BivariateCorr, conf.level = .95) $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Regression Model`           Est      LL      UL Model   0.284   0.000   0.600

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code calculate NHST regression model.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> testModel(BivariateCorr) $`Hypothesis Test for the Regression Model`             F     df1     df2       p Model   3.175   1.000   8.000   0.113

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: section analyses regression coefficients obtained overall model.

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code provide table confidence intervals regression coefficients. code produce graph confidence intervals regression coefficients.  code defaults 95% confidence intervals. can changed desired. graph, possible plot just coefficients predictors (minus intercept) addition changing confidence level. comparison line region practical equivalence can also added.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> estimateCoefficients(BivariateCorr) $`Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -4.417  13.082 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateSummary) |> plotCoefficients(BivariateCorr) (BivariateSummary) |> estimateCoefficients(BivariateCorr, conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE      LL      UL (Intercept)   4.333   3.794  -8.399  17.064 Predictor     0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403 (BivariateSummary) |> plotCoefficients(BivariateCorr, conf.level = .99, line = 0, rope = c(-.5, .5), intercept = FALSE)

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code produce table NHST separately regression coefficients. case, coefficients tested value zero.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> testCoefficients(BivariateCorr) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Regression Coefficients`                 Est      SE       t       p (Intercept)   4.333   3.794   1.142   0.287 Predictor     0.833   0.468   1.782   0.113

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code provide table confidence intervals standardized coefficient. places, code defaults 95% confidence interval. can changed desired.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> standardizeCoefficients(BivariateCorr) $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients`               Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.245   1.912 (BivariateSummary) |> standardizeCoefficients(BivariateCorr, conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Regression Coefficients`               Est      SE      LL      UL Predictor   0.833   0.468  -0.736   2.403

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: section provides analyses individual predicted values.

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code produces plot regression line (confidence prediction intervals suppressed).
code: (BivariateSummary) |> plotRegression(BivariateCorr, interval = "none")

title: Bivariate Regression Summary Statistics Example
text: code provides estimates confidence prediction limits specific value Predictor (value=4). code plots confidence interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.  code plots prediction interval associated regression line labels interval specific value Predictor.
code: (BivariateSummary) |> estimateRegression(BivariateCorr, value = 8) $`Confidence and Prediction Intervals for the Regression Value`       Est   CI.LL   CI.UL   PI.LL   PI.UL 8  11.000   9.553  12.447   6.201  15.799 (BivariateSummary) |> plotRegression(BivariateCorr, value = 8, interval = "confidence") (BivariateSummary) |> plotRegression(BivariateCorr, value = 8, interval = "prediction")

title: Complex OneWay Data Application
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Factor <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(3, 10)) Factor <- factor(Factor, levels = c(1, 2, 3), labels = c("Level1", "Level2", "Level3")) Outcome <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10) OneWayData <- construct(Factor, Outcome)

what: Analyses of a Complex Contrast of Means
title: Complex OneWay Data Application
text: Estimate plot means examination.  Create single contrast compare first group grand mean (requires arithmetic). esimate plot contrast.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateMeans() $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`              M      SE      df      LL      UL Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000   9.418  12.582 Level3  12.000   0.775   9.000  10.248  13.752 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateContrast(contrast = c(2/3, -1/3, -1/3)) $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -2.333   0.458  25.917  -3.275  -1.392 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotContrast(contrast = c(2/3, -1/3, -1/3))

what: Analysis of a Difference Between Two Contrasts
title: Complex OneWay Data Application
text: Rather setting just one contrast, set two contrasts: one Grand Mean one Level 1. Estimate plot confidence intervals contrast difference contrasts.  Enhance plot adding colors removing value labels.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "L1Only")) $`Confidence Intervals for the Contrasts of Means`               Est      SE      df      LL      UL GrandMean  10.333   0.378  23.397   9.551  11.115 L1Only      8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012  $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Contrasts`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -2.333   0.458  25.917  -3.275  -1.392 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "L1Only")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "L1Only"), values = FALSE, col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "black"))

title: Complex Repeated Measures Data Application
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Outcome1 <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7) Outcome2 <- c(7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11) Outcome3 <- c(9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10) RepeatedData <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3)

what: Analyses of a Complex Contrast of Means
title: Complex Repeated Measures Data Application
text: Estimate plot means examination.  Create single contrast compare first variable grand mean (requires arithmetic). esimate plot contrast.
code: (RepeatedData) |> estimateMeans() $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`                M      SE      df      LL      UL Outcome1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012 Outcome2  11.000   0.699   9.000   9.418  12.582 Outcome3  12.000   0.775   9.000  10.248  13.752 (RepeatedData) |> plotMeans() (RepeatedData) |> estimateContrast(contrast = c(2/3, -1/3, -1/3)) $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -2.333   0.382   9.000  -3.197  -1.470 (RepeatedData) |> plotContrast(contrast = c(2/3, -1/3, -1/3))

what: Analysis of a Difference Between Two Contrasts
title: Complex Repeated Measures Data Application
text: Rather setting just one contrast, set two contrasts: one Grand Mean one Level 1. Estimate plot confidence intervals contrast difference contrasts.  Enhance plot adding colors removing value labels.
code: (RepeatedData) |> estimateComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "O1Only")) $`Confidence Intervals for the Contrasts of Means`               Est      SE      df      LL      UL GrandMean  10.333   0.528   9.000   9.138  11.528 O1Only      8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012  $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Contrasts`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -2.333   0.382   9.000  -3.197  -1.470 (RepeatedData) |> plotComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "O1Only")) (RepeatedData) |> plotComplex(contrast1 = c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3), contrast2 = c(1, 0, 0), labels = c("GrandMean", "O1Only"), values = FALSE, col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "black"))

title: Effects Factorial Data Application
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.

title: Effects Factorial Data Application
text: Get ANOVA separately simple effect.
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> describeEffectBy(by = FactorB) $`Source Table for the Model: B1`              SS      df      MS Between  86.667   2.000  43.333 Within  116.000  27.000   4.296  $`Source Table for the Model: B2`              SS      df      MS Between   6.667   2.000   3.333 Within  134.000  27.000   4.963 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> estimateEffectBy(by = FactorB) $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Model: B1`            Est      LL      UL Factor   0.428   0.157   0.569  $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Model: B2`            Est      LL      UL Factor   0.047   0.000   0.173 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> testEffectBy(by = FactorB) $`Hypothesis Test for the Model: B1`              F     df1     df2       p Factor  10.086   2.000  27.000   0.001  $`Hypothesis Test for the Model: B2`              F     df1     df2       p Factor   0.672   2.000  27.000   0.519

title: Effects Factorial Data Application
text: Get summary statistics separately within simple effect. Estimate, plot, test, standardize means separately within simple effect.
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> describeSummaryBy(by = FactorB) $`Summary Statistics for the Data: B1`          N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 A2  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 A3  10.000  12.000   2.449   0.340  -1.102  $`Summary Statistics for the Data: B2`          N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt A1  10.000   8.000   2.449  -0.340  -1.102 A2  10.000   8.000   2.000  -0.417   0.735 A3  10.000   7.000   2.211   0.000   0.665 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> estimateMeansBy(by = FactorB) $`Confidence Intervals for the Means: B1`          M      SE      df      LL      UL A1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012 A2  11.000   0.699   9.000   9.418  12.582 A3  12.000   0.775   9.000  10.248  13.752  $`Confidence Intervals for the Means: B2`          M      SE      df      LL      UL A1   8.000   0.775   9.000   6.248   9.752 A2   8.000   0.632   9.000   6.569   9.431 A3   7.000   0.699   9.000   5.418   8.582 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> plotMeansBy(by = FactorB) (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> testMeansBy(by = FactorB) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Means: B1`       Diff      SE      df       t       p A1   8.000   0.447   9.000  17.889   0.000 A2  11.000   0.699   9.000  15.732   0.000 A3  12.000   0.775   9.000  15.492   0.000  $`Hypothesis Tests for the Means: B2`       Diff      SE      df       t       p A1   8.000   0.775   9.000  10.328   0.000 A2   8.000   0.632   9.000  12.649   0.000 A3   7.000   0.699   9.000  10.011   0.000 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> standardizeMeansBy(by = FactorB) $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Means: B1`          d      SE      LL      UL A1   5.657   1.251   3.005   8.295 A2   4.975   1.111   2.622   7.312 A3   4.899   1.096   2.579   7.203  $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Means: B2`          d      SE      LL      UL A1   3.266   0.771   1.644   4.863 A2   4.000   0.915   2.068   5.911 A3   3.166   0.752   1.586   4.721

title: Effects Factorial Data Application
text: Analyze specified comparison separately within simple effect.
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> estimateDifferenceBy(by = FactorB) $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means: B1`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.308   1.234   4.766  $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means: B2`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   0.000   1.000  17.308  -2.107   2.107 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> plotDifferenceBy(by = FactorB) (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> testDifferenceBy(by = FactorB) $`Hypothesis Test for the Difference of Means: B1`               Diff      SE      df       t       p Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.308   3.614   0.002  $`Hypothesis Test for the Difference of Means: B2`               Diff      SE      df       t       p Comparison   0.000   1.000  17.308   0.000   1.000 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> standardizeDifferenceBy(by = FactorB) $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Difference of Means: B1`                  d      SE      LL      UL Comparison   1.616   0.555   0.529   2.703  $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Difference of Means: B2`                  d      SE      LL      UL Comparison   0.000   0.471  -0.924   0.924

title: Effects Factorial Data Application
text: Analyze specified contrast separately within simple effect.
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> estimateContrastBy(by = FactorB, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means: B1`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast   3.500   0.687  25.917   2.087   4.913  $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means: B2`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -0.500   0.907  15.806  -2.424   1.424 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> plotContrastBy(by = FactorB, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> testContrastBy(by = FactorB, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Hypothesis Test for the Contrast of Means: B1`              Est      SE      df       t       p Contrast   3.500   0.687  25.917   5.093   0.000  $`Hypothesis Test for the Contrast of Means: B2`              Est      SE      df       t       p Contrast  -0.500   0.907  15.806  -0.551   0.589 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> standardizeContrastBy(by = FactorB, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Contrast of Means: B1`              Est      SE      LL      UL Contrast   1.689   0.428   0.850   2.527  $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Contrast of Means: B2`              Est      SE      LL      UL Contrast  -0.224   0.430  -1.068   0.619

title: Effects Mixed Data Application
text: Analyze specified contrast separately within simple effect.
code: construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) |> estimateContrastBy(by = Factor, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means: Level1`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast   3.500   0.573   9.000   2.205   4.795  $`Confidence Interval for the Contrast of Means: Level2`              Est      SE      df      LL      UL Contrast  -0.500   0.810   9.000  -2.332   1.332 construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) |> plotContrastBy(by = Factor, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) |> testContrastBy(by = Factor, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Hypothesis Test for the Contrast of Means: Level1`              Est      SE      df       t       p Contrast   3.500   0.573   9.000   6.113   0.000  $`Hypothesis Test for the Contrast of Means: Level2`              Est      SE      df       t       p Contrast  -0.500   0.810   9.000  -0.618   0.552 construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) |> standardizeContrastBy(by = Factor, contrast = c(-1, .5, .5)) $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Contrast of Means: Level1`              Est      SE      LL      UL Contrast   1.689   0.371   0.962   2.415  $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Contrast of Means: Level2`              Est      SE      LL      UL Contrast  -0.224   0.341  -0.892   0.443

title: Exploratory OneWay Data Application
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Factor <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(3, 10)) Factor <- factor(Factor, levels = c(1, 2, 3), labels = c("Level1", "Level2", "Level3")) Outcome <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10) OneWayData <- construct(Factor, Outcome)

title: Exploratory OneWay Data Application
text: typical way build plot use separate calls plotting elements (e.g., data, boxplots) using “add” parameter put plot.  can simplified using “add” version function call instead using longer “add” parameter function call.  Rather separate lines function calls, plotting elements passthrough capabilities allow placed line.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotData() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotBoxes(add = TRUE) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotData() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> addBoxes() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotData() |> addBoxes()

title: Exploratory OneWay Data Application
text: Obtain violin plots using one call (enhance plot).  Obtain bean plots using one call (enhance plot).  Obtain raincloud plots using one call (enhance plot).
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotViolins(col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotBeans(col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod")) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotRainclouds(col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod"))

title: Factorial Data Example
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame. code subsets data two different data frames (simple effects analysis).
code: FactorA <- c(rep(1, 20), rep(2, 20), rep(3, 20)) FactorA <- factor(FactorA, levels = c(1, 2, 3), labels = c("A1", "A2", "A3")) FactorB <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10)) FactorB <- factor(FactorB, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("B1", "B2")) Outcome <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 5, 9, 10, 9, 11, 4, 11, 7, 6, 8, 7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 7, 8, 7, 11, 10, 7, 8, 4, 8, 10, 9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10, 8, 6, 8, 11, 5, 7, 9, 3, 6, 7) FactorialData <- construct(FactorA, FactorB, Outcome) FactorialDataB1 <- subset(FactorialData, FactorB == "B1") FactorialDataB2 <- subset(FactorialData, FactorB == "B2")

code: Level1 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 1.414) Level2 <- c(N = 10, M = 11.000, SD = 2.211) IndependentSummary <- construct(Level1, Level2, class = "bss")

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code confirms descriptive statistics summary table.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`              N       M      SD Level1  10.000   8.000   1.414 Level2  10.000  11.000   2.211

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: section produces analyses equivalent one-sample analyses separately level factor.

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code provide table confidence intervals level factor. code produce graph confidence intervals level factor.  code defaults 95% confidence intervals. can changed desired. graph, possible add comparison line represent population (test) value region practical equivalence addition changing confidence level.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> estimateMeans() $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`              M      SE      df      LL      UL Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000   9.418  12.582 (IndependentSummary) |> plotMeans() (IndependentSummary) |> estimateMeans(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`              M      SE      df      LL      UL Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.547   9.453 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000   8.728  13.272 (IndependentSummary) |> plotMeans(conf.level = .99, line = 9, rope = c(8, 10))

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code produce table NHST separately level factor. case, means tested value zero. Often, default test value zero meaningful plausible. can altered (often conjunction presented plot).
code: (IndependentSummary) |> testMeans() $`Hypothesis Tests for the Means`           Diff      SE      df       t       p Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000  17.891   0.000 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000  15.733   0.000 (IndependentSummary) |> testMeans(mu = 9) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Means`           Diff      SE      df       t       p Level1  -1.000   0.447   9.000  -2.236   0.052 Level2   2.000   0.699   9.000   2.860   0.019

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code produce table standardized mean differences separately level factor. case, mean compared zero form effect size. possible alter width confidence intervals establish plausible comparison value mean.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> standardizeMeans() $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Means`              d      SE      LL      UL Level1   5.658   1.251   3.005   8.297 Level2   4.975   1.111   2.622   7.312 (IndependentSummary) |> standardizeMeans(mu = 9, conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Standardized Means`              d      SE      LL      UL Level1  -0.707   0.364  -1.614   0.222 Level2   0.905   0.384  -0.083   1.873

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code estimates confidence interval difference. code obtains plots confidence intervals groups mean difference .  course, can change confidence level default 95% desired. , confidence levels can changed away default comparison line represent population (test) value region practical equivalence can added graph.  wish, can get confidence intervals means mean difference one command. code produces difference plot using confidence intervals means mean difference.  course, can change confidence level default 95% desired. , confidence levels can changed away default region practical equivalence can added graph.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> estimateDifference() $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.307   1.234   4.766 (IndependentSummary) |> plotDifference() (IndependentSummary) |> estimateDifference(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.307   0.561   5.439 (IndependentSummary) |> plotDifference(conf.level = .99, line = 0, rope = c(-2, 2)) (IndependentSummary) |> estimateComparison() $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`              M      SE      df      LL      UL Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.988   9.012 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000   9.418  12.582  $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.307   1.234   4.766 (IndependentSummary) |> plotComparison() (IndependentSummary) |> estimateComparison(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Intervals for the Means`              M      SE      df      LL      UL Level1   8.000   0.447   9.000   6.547   9.453 Level2  11.000   0.699   9.000   8.728  13.272  $`Confidence Interval for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df      LL      UL Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.307   0.561   5.439 (IndependentSummary) |> plotComparison(conf.level = .99, rope = c(-2, 2))

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code produces NHST mean difference (using default test value zero). default value zero plausible, can changed.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> testDifference() $`Hypothesis Test for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df       t       p Comparison   3.000   0.830  15.307   3.615   0.002 (IndependentSummary) |> testDifference(mu = 2) $`Hypothesis Test for the Difference of Means`               Diff      SE      df       t       p Comparison   1.000   0.830  15.307   1.205   0.247

title: Independent Groups Summary Statistics Example
text: code calculates standardized mean difference confidence interval. width confidence interval effect size can altered desired.
code: (IndependentSummary) |> standardizeDifference() $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Difference of Means`                  d      SE      LL      UL Comparison   1.617   0.555   0.530   2.704 (IndependentSummary) |> standardizeDifference(conf.level = .99) $`Confidence Interval for the Standardized Difference of Means`                  d      SE      LL      UL Comparison   1.617   0.555   0.188   3.045

text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.

title: Interaction Factorial Data Application
text: Get ANOVA design whole, including source table, estimate proportion variance accounted , ANOVA test main effects interaction. Plot means confidence intervals design whole.
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> describeFactorial(by = FactorB) $`Source Table for the Model: Between Subjects`                    SS      df      MS Factor        106.667   1.000 106.667 Blocks         30.000   2.000  15.000 Factor:Blocks  63.333   2.000  31.667 Residual      250.000  54.000   4.630 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> estimateFactorial(by = FactorB) $`Proportion of Variance Accounted For by the Model: Between Subjects`                   Est      LL      UL Factor          0.299   0.136   0.437 Blocks          0.107   0.000   0.176 Factor:Blocks   0.202   0.014   0.248 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> testFactorial(by = FactorB) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Model: Between Subjects`                     F     df1     df2       p Factor         23.040   1.000  54.000   0.000 Blocks          3.240   2.000  54.000   0.047 Factor:Blocks   6.840   2.000  54.000   0.002 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> plotFactorial(by = FactorB, col = c("darkred", "darkblue")) legend("topleft", inset = .01, box.lty = 0, pch = 16, legend = c("B1", "B2"), col = c("darkred", "darkblue"))

title: Interaction Factorial Data Application
text: Identify 2 x 2 interaction interest (case, two levels FactorA existing two levels FactorB). Estimate, plot, test interaction contrast (includes comparisons within simple effect).
code: (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> estimateInteraction(by = FactorB) $`Confidence Intervals for the Simple Effect Constrasts`                         Est      SE      df      LL      UL Simple Effect at B1   3.000   0.830  15.308   1.234   4.766 Simple Effect at B2   0.000   1.000  17.308  -2.107   2.107  $`Confidence Interval for the Interaction Contrast`                 Est      SE      df      LL      UL Interaction  -3.000   1.300  32.129  -5.647  -0.353 (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> plotInteraction(by = FactorB) (Outcome ~ FactorA) |> focus(A1, A2) |> testInteraction(by = FactorB) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Main Effect Constrasts`                         Est      SE       t      df       p Simple Effect at B1   3.000   0.830   3.614  15.308   0.002 Simple Effect at B2   0.000   1.000   0.000  17.308   1.000  $`Hypothesis Test for the Interaction Contrast`                 Est      SE       t      df       p Interaction   3.000   1.300   2.308  32.129   0.028

code: construct(Outcome1, Outcome2) |> estimateInteraction(by = Factor) $`Confidence Intervals for the Simple Effect Constrasts`                             Est      SE      df      LL      UL Simple Effect at Level1   3.000   0.596   9.000   1.651   4.349 Simple Effect at Level2   0.000   0.775   9.000  -1.752   1.752  $`Confidence Interval for the Interaction Contrast`                 Est      SE      df      LL      UL Interaction  -3.000   0.978  16.894  -5.063  -0.937 construct(Outcome1, Outcome2) |> testInteraction(by = Factor) $`Hypothesis Tests for the Main Effect Constrasts`                             Est      SE       t      df       p Simple Effect at Level1   3.000   0.596   5.031   9.000   0.001 Simple Effect at Level2   0.000   0.775   0.000   9.000   1.000  $`Hypothesis Test for the Interaction Contrast`                 Est      SE       t      df       p Interaction  -3.000   0.978  -3.069  16.894   0.007 construct(Outcome1, Outcome2) |> plotInteraction(by = Factor)

title: Introduction
text: EASI designed offer simple, intuitive, consistent way implement estimation statistics R. following goals set scope project: Functions generally limited means (functions means), correlations, regression coefficients Analyses can conducted using either raw data summary statistics (means, standard deviations, correlations) Calculations run underlying functions regardless type input Output utilizes consistent layouts labeling across different types analyses

title: Introduction
text: EASI offers general convention function names. function first comprised prefix (verb indicates procedure conducted). basic options (though elaborate functions also exist): describe = describe data model summary statistics estimate = estimate statistic confidence interval plot = plot descriptive statistics estimates test = test estimates statistical significance standardize = standardize estimate provide confidence interval functions append appropriate statistical element (noun indicates statistics items analyzed), Means Correlations.

title: Introduction
text: standard R syntax, function name followed parentheses variables analyzed relevant additional parameters (different confidence levels, null values, etc.). R versions 4.1 greater, native pipe operator can used instead standard syntax. , variables analyzed included first, followed pipe operator, function call (relevant additional parameters parentheses). format used throughout EASI. individual variables directly accessible (like dataset predefined) using subsets larger datasets (like analyzing factorial designs), typically necessary identify data first select variables within data set. base R, accomplished using command (built data identification parameters). EASI, accomplished using focus command (many related uses well).
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateMeans() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateMeans(conf.level = .99, main = "Custom Table Title", digits = 2) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans() (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans(values = FALSE, main = "Custom Plot Title", col = "darkblue") OneWayData |> focus(Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateMeans() OneWayData |> focus(Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateMeans(conf.level = .99, main = "Custom Table Title", digits = 2) OneWayData |> focus(Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans() OneWayData |> focus(Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotMeans(values = FALSE, main = "Custom Plot Title", col = "darkblue")

title: Mixed Design Data Example
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame. code subsets data two different data frames (simple effects analysis).
code: Factor <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10)) Factor <- factor(Factor, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("Level1", "Level2")) Outcome1 <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 5, 9, 10, 9, 11, 4, 11, 7, 6, 8) Outcome2 <- c(7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 7, 8, 7, 11, 10, 7, 8, 4, 8, 10) Outcome3 <- c(9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10, 8, 6, 8, 11, 5, 7, 9, 3, 6, 7) MixedData <- construct(Factor, Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3) MixedDataL1 <- subset(MixedData, Factor == "Level1") MixedDataL2 <- subset(MixedData, Factor == "Level2")

title: Mixed Design Data Example
text: code obtains descriptive statistics two data frames.
code: (MixedDataL1) |> focus(Outcome1,Outcome2,Outcome3) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt Outcome1  10.000   8.000   1.414   0.000  -0.738 Outcome2  10.000  11.000   2.211  -0.617  -0.212 Outcome3  10.000  12.000   2.449   0.340  -1.102 (MixedDataL1) |> focus(Outcome1,Outcome2,Outcome3) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`          Outcome1 Outcome2 Outcome3 Outcome1    1.000    0.533    0.385 Outcome2    0.533    1.000    0.574 Outcome3    0.385    0.574    1.000 (MixedDataL2) |> focus(Outcome1,Outcome2,Outcome3) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                N       M      SD    Skew    Kurt Outcome1  10.000   8.000   2.449  -0.340  -1.102 Outcome2  10.000   8.000   2.000  -0.417   0.735 Outcome3  10.000   7.000   2.211   0.000   0.665 (MixedDataL2) |> focus(Outcome1,Outcome2,Outcome3) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`          Outcome1 Outcome2 Outcome3 Outcome1    1.000    0.408    0.164 Outcome2    0.408    1.000    0.553 Outcome3    0.164    0.553    1.000

title: Mixed Design Summary Statistics Example
text: code inputs variable summaries creates summary table. code creates correlation matrix. repeat process create second subset. correlation matrix second subset.
code: Outcome1 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 1.414) Outcome2 <- c(N = 10, M = 11.000, SD = 2.211) Outcome3 <- c(N = 10, M = 12.000, SD = 2.449) MixedSummaryL1 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "wss") Outcome1 <- c(1.000, .533, .385) Outcome2 <- c(.533, 1.000, .574) Outcome3 <- c(.385, .574, 1.000) MixedCorrL1 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "corr") Outcome1 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 2.449) Outcome2 <- c(N = 10, M = 8.000, SD = 2.000) Outcome3 <- c(N = 10, M = 7.000, SD = 2.211) MixedSummaryL2 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "wss") Outcome1 <- c(1.000, .408, .164) Outcome2 <- c(.408, 1.000, .553) Outcome3 <- c(.164, .553, 1.000) MixedCorrL2 <- construct(Outcome1, Outcome2, Outcome3, class = "corr")

title: Mixed Design Summary Statistics Example
text: code confirms descriptive statistics summary tables.
code: (MixedSummaryL1) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                N       M      SD Outcome1  10.000   8.000   1.414 Outcome2  10.000  11.000   2.211 Outcome3  10.000  12.000   2.449 (MixedCorrL1) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`          Outcome1 Outcome2 Outcome3 Outcome1    1.000    0.533    0.385 Outcome2    0.533    1.000    0.574 Outcome3    0.385    0.574    1.000 (MixedSummaryL2) |> describeSummary() $`Summary Statistics for the Data`                N       M      SD Outcome1  10.000   8.000   2.449 Outcome2  10.000   8.000   2.000 Outcome3  10.000   7.000   2.211 (MixedCorrL2) |> describeCorrelations() $`Correlation Matrix for the Variables`          Outcome1 Outcome2 Outcome3 Outcome1    1.000    0.408    0.164 Outcome2    0.408    1.000    0.553 Outcome3    0.164    0.553    1.000

title: Pairwise OneWay Data Application
text: code inputs variable names creates viewable data frame.
code: Factor <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(3, 10)) Factor <- factor(Factor, levels = c(1, 2, 3), labels = c("Level1", "Level2", "Level3")) Outcome <- c(6, 8, 6, 8, 10, 8, 10, 9, 8, 7, 7, 13, 11, 10, 13, 8, 11, 14, 12, 11, 9, 16, 11, 12, 15, 13, 9, 14, 11, 10) OneWayData <- construct(Factor, Outcome)

title: Pairwise OneWay Data Application
text: Provide ANOVA source table.
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> describeEffect() $`Source Table for the Model`              SS      df      MS Between  86.667   2.000  43.333 Within  116.000  27.000   4.296 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> testEffect() $`Hypothesis Test for the Model`              F     df1     df2       p Factor  10.086   2.000  27.000   0.001

title: Pairwise OneWay Data Application
text: analyses pairwise comparisons assume homogeneity variance make adjustments multiple comparisons (therefore effectively equivalent series independent samples t tests). Obtain tables interval estimates pairwise comparisons, tests statistical significance, standardized effect sizes. Provide traditional plot confidence intervals pairwise comparisons (including line represents difference comparisons).  Provide diffogram (plot means confidence intervals pairwise comparisons) specify colors intervals include zero (darkblue) include zero (darkred).
code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimatePairwise() $`Confidence Intervals for the Pairwise Comparisons of Means`                      MD      SE      df      LL      UL Level1 v Level2   3.000   0.830  15.308   1.234   4.766 Level1 v Level3   4.000   0.894  14.400   2.087   5.913 Level2 v Level3   1.000   1.043  17.815  -1.194   3.194 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> testPairwise() $`Hypothesis Tests for the Pairwise Comparisons of Means`                      MD      SE      df       t       p Level1 v Level2   3.000   0.830  15.308   3.614   0.002 Level1 v Level3   4.000   0.894  14.400   4.472   0.000 Level2 v Level3   1.000   1.043  17.815   0.958   0.351 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> standardizePairwise() $`Confidence Intervals for the Pairwise Standardized Comparisons of Means`                       d      SE      LL      UL Level1 v Level2   1.616   0.555   0.529   2.703 Level1 v Level3   2.000   0.601   0.822   3.178 Level2 v Level3   0.429   0.477  -0.506   1.363 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotPairwise(line = 0, values = FALSE) (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotPairwiseDiffogram(col = c("darkblue", "darkred"))

title: Pairwise OneWay Data Application

code: (Outcome ~ Factor) |> estimateRelational() $`Confidence and Relational Intervals for the Means`              M   RI.LL   RI.UL   CI.LL   CI.UL Level1   8.000   7.049   8.951   6.988   9.012 Level2  11.000  10.049  11.951   9.418  12.582 Level3  12.000  11.049  12.951  10.248  13.752 (Outcome ~ Factor) |> plotRelational(col = c("darkred", "darkblue", "darkgoldenrod"))

title: Pairwise OneWay Data Application
text: analyses post hoc comparisons assume homogeneity variance make adjustments multiple comparisons (based Tukey HSD procedures). code: @Manual{,   title = {EASI: Estimation Approach to Statistical Inference},   author = {Craig Wendorf},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 5.5.231128},   url = {https://github.com/cwendorf/EASI}, }

title: Estimation Approach to Statistical Inference
text: EASI R package implements features estimation statistics data visualization pipe-oriented framework. primary functions describe, estimate, test, plot confidence intervals means, mean comparisons, correlations, standardized effect sizes - within-subjects single-factor, factorial, mixed designs. functions can take either raw data summary statistics input. Additional functions extend analysis capabilities much . extensions also offer summaries plots data, frequencies, densities, . features can combined produce images similar estimation statistics implementations.

title: Estimation Approach to Statistical Inference
text: R package currently CRAN, latest version can installed loaded using R commands: wish full install, latest functions can made available using R commands:
code: install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("cwendorf/EASI") library(EASI) source("http://raw.githubusercontent.com/cwendorf/EASI/main/source-EASI.R")
